subject: RE: [junit] JDK 1.5 annotations a la nUnit
msgSnippet: ... Let s hope so. That would be cool. But there seems to be a rather low rate of adoption of nunit (at least judging by the mailing lists). Thanks
messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, January 26, 2005 2:52 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] JDK 1.5 annotations a la nUnit
> ...
> Michael Schuerig wrote:
> > On Wednesday 26 January 2005 03:46, ezra_epstein wrote:
> > > I did some work with .NET a while back. The nUnit port was pretty
cool:
> > > : annotations, rather than naming conventions, are used to ...
> > >
> > > I'm wondering, now that annotations have been added to Java, is
> > > anyone working on reverse-porting nUnit? ...
> >
> > I'm wondering, what is the advantage?
>
> Well, Ruby and Smalltalk programmers can do neat things with
> tests that Java programmers can't do,...
>
> As to what those neat things are, I won't know until I try
> using such a thing in anger. My guess is that there are C# programmers out

> there who have a thing or two to teach us about tests and inheritance,
> since NUnit works (more or less) like RUnit and SUnit do.

Let's hope so. That would be cool. But there seems to be a rather low rate
of adoption of nunit (at least judging by the mailing lists).

Thanks
